intro: Campanula lehmanniana subsp. lehmanniana, commonly known as the Lehmann's bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It is characterized by its bell-shaped blue to violet flowers that bloom in early summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with opposite, lance-shaped leaves that are covered in fine hairs. It prefers well-drained soils and full sun to partial shade, often found in rocky or alpine habitats. Its ornamental value makes it a sought-after plant in gardens, though it is relatively rare in cultivation.
